name: App
//homepageComment: This is required for React to use the correct path for file:// requests in production

scripts.electron-start: npm run electron-build && cross-env ELECTRON_IS_DEV=1 electron .
scripts.start: concurrently "npm run react-start" "wait-on http://localhost:3000/ && npm run electron-start"
scripts.build: npm run electron-build && npm run react-build

//scriptsComments.react-start: Start the React app in development mode, which will auto-reload the app when files are changed.
//scriptsComments.electron-start: Start electron in development mode, i.e. use the React app running on http://localhost:3000
//scriptsComments.start-web: Start the React app in development mode on port 3001 and automatically open in your web Browser. Electron-dependent features will be missing in the browser.
//scriptsComments.start-prod: Given that `npm run build` has been run, run the app in production mode, i.e. run electron and use build/index.html as the entry point
//scriptsComments.react-build: Compile the React app into the build folder
//scriptsComments.electron-build: Compile the electron/electron.ts TypeScript file into JavaScript
//scriptsComments.build: Build the React app and the electron script
//scriptsComments.react-test: Run tests defined in files matching src/*.test.* (e.g. App.test.tsx)
//scriptsComments.test: Run React tests, and should include other types of tests as they are added
//scriptsComments.lint: Check for code errors/warnings. These should automatically show in the VS Code editor, so you usually don't need to run this command.
//scriptsComments.package: Create standalone executable for your computer's platform. The --ignore option ensures that only the needed files are included.
//scriptsComments.package-<platform>: Create standalone executable for a specific platform. Platform-specific command line options for electron-packager can be set.

//dependenciesComments.electron-context-menu: Add a right-click menu to Electron, including Inspect Element in development mode
//dependenciesComments.electron-is-dev: Detect if electron is running in development mode

//devDependenciesComments.NOTE: devDependencies aren't included in node_modules in the packaged app. Development tools and dependencies for the React app should go here, since those dependencies get compiled into the React build.
//devDependenciesComments.@craco/craco: Create React App Configuration Override - needed to configure PostCSS (used for Tailwind CSS). Acts as a wrapper for react-scripts
//devDependenciesComments.@tailwindcss/forms: Official Tailwind CSS plugin needed by VechaiUI
//devDependenciesComments.@types/<>: TypeScript type definitions for various packages
//devDependenciesComments.@typescript-eslint/parser: TypeScript parsing support for ESLint (the parser converts the code into a data structure that the linter can understand)
//devDependenciesComments.@vechaiui/<>: VechaiUI - Plug-n-play component library built on top of Tailwind CSS
//devDependenciesComments.autoprefixer: The most ubiquitous PostCSS plugin, and needed by Tailwind CSS
//devDependenciesComments.check-dependencies: Check if all the dependencies are installed according to this file - much faster than just running `npm install`
//devDependenciesComments.concurrently: Run two commands concurrently in the same terminal
//devDependenciesComments.cross-env: Allows setting environment variables for both Unix and Windows
//devDependenciesComments.electron: PRIMARY LIBRARY. Chromium, but modified to provide access to Node.js from a web frontend and enable building cross-platform desktop apps
//devDependenciesComments.electron-packager: Package the app into an executable for any platform
//devDependenciesComments.eslint-config-prettier: Turns off ESLint rules that would conflict with Prettier.
//devDependenciesComments.eslint-plugin-no-autofix: Include ESLint rules that you want to be flagged but not auto-fixed (useful for prefer-const)
//devDependenciesComments.eslint-plugin-prettier: ESLint plugin that runs Prettier as an ESLint rule
//devDependenciesComments.immer: Make it easy to generate the next state in Redux reducers
//devDependenciesComments.postcss: Allows writing more powerful CSS by transforming your CSS files based on plugins you install
//devDependenciesComments.prettier: Code formatter to make code look pretty
//devDependenciesComments.react-scripts: Tools for running, building, and testing the React app, specific to create-react-app
//devDependenciesComments.redux: PRIMARY LIBRARY. State management library - manages how all the data in the app is updated and used
//devDependenciesComments.redux-devtools-extension: Helps setup the Redux Devtools Chrome extension

//devDependenciesComments.socket.io-client: Exchange messages with a Socket.IO server
